Situation1: They notice dust and mess building up and carry out more regular cleaning tasks.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: I glanced at the clock as I wiped down the kitchen counters, the rag in my hand moving faster with every passing minute. The living room still needed vacuuming, and I could see dust gathering in the corners, taunting me. As a housekeeping cleaner, I prided myself on leaving every space spotless, and the thought of missing a single crumb made my skin crawl. But my phone buzzed with a reminder: my volunteer shift started in twenty minutes. I was supposed to be there on time, ready to help, even though I knew the others could cover for me if I was a little late. Still, I hated the idea of letting anyone down. My mind raced, torn between the growing mess in front of me and the commitment waiting across town. I could feel the pressure building in my chest, the weight of two sets of expectations pulling me in opposite directions. I stood frozen, rag in hand, caught between the urge to scrub away every speck of dust and the responsibility to show up for those who needed me.
